55: Bleeding after 28 weeks of pregnancy can be due to two reasons - either abruption of the placenta or placenta previa. Abruption of the placenta is when the afterbirth separates from the uterus, which can cause pain, abdominal cramps and changes in the baby's heart rate. Placenta previa is when the placenta is attached to the lower part of the uterus, and it typically causes painless vaginal bleeding. It is important for you to be evaluated by having an ultrasound to check the position of the placenta and to see if there is any collection behind it. It is also recommended to have your blood cross-matched and ready in case you experience any excessive bleeding, and to have your hemoglobin and clotting levels checked. Please contact your gynecologist as soon as possible for further evaluation. I hope this information helps. Take care.

2399: Blood dialysis is a treatment method used to remove waste products from the blood, but cancer cells do not simply feed on the blood like other cells in the body. Their genetic code is different and they have the ability to multiply and resist treatment. In fact, some cancer cells may be in a resting phase and not actively spreading, making it difficult to target and eliminate them. Chemotherapy and other treatments are designed to attack active cancer cells, but resistance and recurrence can occur due to varying phases of the cell cycle. Hi, Thank you for reaching out. From the information you have provided, it seems that your brother has a calcified granuloma in the right occipital region of his brain. This type of granuloma is usually a result of an infection from the tapeworm parasite. It is important to note that the infection usually occurs through contaminated food and water.

In your brother's case, the calcified stage means that the granuloma is in a healed state and is less likely to cause seizures. However, the fact that he has experienced seizures for the past 6 years suggests that the granuloma may still be causing sudden electrical activity in his brain.

To determine if the granuloma is active or inactive, I would recommend an electroencephalogram (EEG) to study the abnormal electrical activity in his brain. Additionally, he may need to be treated with anti-epileptic medications and possibly an anti-parasitic if there is any evidence of an active neurocysticercosis lesion. It is also important to monitor for any brain swelling, which may require further treatment.

If the granuloma is completely calcified, it is considered to be inactive. However, it is important to repeat the scan periodically to check for any recent activity. 2971: Hello Katarina, thank you for reaching out. Phototherapy (or NB-UV B phototherapy) is considered to be one of the most effective treatments for widespread plaque psoriasis. I suggest discussing phototherapy further with your nephew's dermatologist as it can be a long-term safe option for managing psoriasis.
